input: Welcome back, everybody.
It's hard to define exactly what mathematicians mean when they use the phrase problem solving.
However you go about it, it's going to involve some notion of approaching puzzles that you've never seen before and still being able to systematically and creatively find some solution to them.
But that's a weird thing when you think about it because it makes it a very hard thing to teach.
I mean, you can teach someone how to solve one particular problem, maybe even a class of problems, and teach them how to solve another problem.
But how do you teach someone how to approach a problem that they've never seen before and still make progress on it?
Well, I honestly don't know how, but what I want to do for this lecture is to talk through a couple different problem solving principles.
I've enumerated nine of them in total, and each one we're going to walk through in the context of a specific example.
And I think each one is kind of simple.
You'll look at it and you'll nod along thinking, yeah, yeah, of course that's a thing that you should do.

But I would argue that each one is deceptively simple, that you would be shocked at how often you can make very meaningful progress in very hard problems just by keeping some of these tips in the back of your mind.
